00040 #ifndef _physworld_cpp
00041 #define _physworld_cpp
00042 ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00043 //The world that integrates everything
00044 //
00045 //This is where all the calls to the the underlying libraries should be from.
00046 //PhysWorld is an abstraction layer to all of the non-ui libraries. The ui
00047 //layers wx and ogre both have their own main loops, so it is almost mandatory
00048 //for other code to interact with those libraries directly.
00049 ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00050 //Includes
00051 #include "physdatatypes.h"
00052 #include "event.h"
00053 #include "physworld.h"
00054 #include "physvector.h"

00056 #include "physworldcallbackmanager.h"
00057 #include "graphicsettings.h"
00058 #include "physactor.h"
00059 #include "physeventuserinput.h"

00071 // Physworld constructor
00072 //this should create the basic objects for stroing and tracking the roots of
00073 //objects in the game
00074 /// @todo TODO Fix the `const`ness of all methods to be as const as allowable
00075 PhysWorld::PhysWorld()
00076 {
00077     PhysVector3 Lbounds(-1000.0,-1000.0,-1000.0);
00078     PhysVector3 Ubounds(1000.0,1000.0,1000.0);
00079 
00080         this->Construct(
00081                 Lbounds,
00082                 Ubounds,
00083                 10
00084                 );
00085 }

00088 
00089 PhysWorld::PhysWorld(   const PhysVector3 &GeographyLowerBounds_,
00090                         const PhysVector3 &GeographyUpperbounds_,
00091                         const unsigned short int  &MaxPhysicsProxies_)
00092 {
00093         this->Construct(GeographyLowerBounds_,
00094                     GeographyUpperbounds_,
00095                     MaxPhysicsProxies_
00096                     );
00097 }
00098 
00099 void PhysWorld::Construct(  const PhysVector3 &GeographyLowerBounds_,
00100                             const PhysVector3 &GeographyUpperbounds_,
00101                             const unsigned short int &MaxPhysicsProxies_)
00102 {
00103     //Set some sane Defaults for some values
00104     this->SetWindowName("AppName");
00105     this->TargetFrameLength=16;
00106     this->HasSDLBeenInitialized=false;
00107     this->PhysicsStepsize = btScalar(1.)/btScalar(60.);
00108 
00109         PlayerSettings = new GraphicsSettings();
00110 
00111         //We create our Ogre environment
00112         this->OgreRoot = new Ogre::Root(crossplatform::GetPluginsDotCFG(),crossplatform::GetSettingsDotCFG(),"Physgame.log");
00113     this->OgreResource = Ogre::ResourceGroupManager::getSingletonPtr();
00114 
00115     // This Tests various assumptions about the wa ythe platform works, and will not akk
00116     SanityChecks();
00117 
00118     //Callbacks are the main way that a game using the PhysWorld will be able to have their code run at custom times
00119         this->CallBacks = new PhysWorldCallBackManager(this);
00120     //Events are the main way for the game using the physworld to  get information about the various subsystems
00121     this->Events = new PhysEventManager(this);
00122 
00123         //instantiate the Physics engine and related items
00124         GeographyLowerBounds = GeographyLowerBounds_;
00125         GeographyUpperbounds = GeographyUpperbounds_;
00126         MaxPhysicsProxies = MaxPhysicsProxies_;
00127 
00128         btVector3 worldAabbMin(GeographyLowerBounds.X, GeographyLowerBounds.Y, GeographyLowerBounds.Z);
00129         btVector3 worldAabbMax(GeographyUpperbounds.X, GeographyUpperbounds.Y, GeographyUpperbounds.Z);
00130 
00131         this->BulletBroadphase = new btAxisSweep3(worldAabbMin, worldAabbMax, MaxPhysicsProxies);
00132         this->BulletSolver = new btSequentialImpulseConstraintSolver;
00133         this->BulletCollisionConfiguration = new btDefaultCollisionConfiguration();
00134         this->BulletDispatcher = new btCollisionDispatcher(BulletCollisionConfiguration);
00135 
00136         this->BulletDynamicsWorld = new btSoftRigidDynamicsWorld(
00137                                                                                                 BulletDispatcher,
00138                                                                                                 BulletBroadphase,
00139                                                                                                 BulletSolver,
00140                                                                                                 BulletCollisionConfiguration);
00141 }
00142 
00143 void PhysWorld::SanityChecks()
00144 {
00145     //Perform a Test that only needs to be done once for the SDL/Physuserinputevent system.
00146     Log("Verifying size of userinput events:");
00147     Log(sizeof(MetaCode::InputCode));
00148     Log(sizeof(SDLKey));
00149     Log(sizeof(int));
00150     if(sizeof(MetaCode::InputCode) != sizeof(SDLKey))
00151     {
00152         LogAndThrow("User input subsystem Event Sizes  Don't match, userinput subsystem will go down faster than 'that' girl on prom night.");
00153     }else{
00154         Log("External User input subsystem Event Sizes match, the User Input subsystem won't crash instantly");
00155     }
00156 
00157     if(sizeof(MetaCode::InputCode) != sizeof(int))
00158     {
00159         LogAndThrow("Internal User input subsystem Event Sizes Don't match, userinput subsystem cannot function.");
00160     }else{
00161         Log("Internal User input subsystem Event Sizes match, the User Input subsystem won't crash instantly");
00162     }
00163 
00164     TestLogger();
00165 }
00166 
00167 void PhysWorld::TestLogger()
00168 {
00169     Log("Testing Logger with all data types");
00170     string temp0("0");
00171     char temp1 = 'a';
00172     short int temp2 = 2;
00173     int temp3 = 3;
00174     long int temp4 = 4;
00175     unsigned short int temp5 = 5;
00176     unsigned int temp6 = 6;
00177     unsigned long int temp7 = 7;
00178     bool temp8 = true;
00179     float temp9 = 0.9;
00180     double temp10 = 9.9999;
00181     long double temp11 = 11.00011;
00182     wchar_t temp12 = 'L';
00183     size_t temp13 = 13;
00184     PhysReal temp14 = 1.4;
00185     PhysWhole temp15 = 15;
00186     PhysString temp16("16 or so");
00187     PhysVector3 temp17(0,1,7);
00188     RawEvent temp18;
00189         temp18.type = SDL_KEYDOWN;
00190         temp18.key.keysym.sym = SDLK_BACKSPACE;
00191     MetaCode temp19(temp18);
00192     btVector3 temp20(1,1,1);
00193     Ogre::Vector3 temp21(2,2,2);
00194     //dynamic_cast<PhysEvent*>// Add physevent as something that can be logged.
00195     /// @todo TODO add each type of event here (logtest) to make it really easy to log events
00196 
00197     OneLogTest(temp0, "string");
00198     OneLogTest(temp1, "char");
00199     OneLogTest(temp2, "short int");
00200     OneLogTest(temp3, "int");
00201     OneLogTest(temp4, "long int");
00202     OneLogTest(temp5, "unsigned short int");
00203     OneLogTest(temp6, "unsigned int");
00204     OneLogTest(temp7, "unsigned long int");
00205     OneLogTest(temp8, "bool");
00206     OneLogTest(temp9, "float");
00207     OneLogTest(temp10, "double");
00208     OneLogTest(temp11, "long double");
00209     OneLogTest(temp12, "wchar_t");
00210     OneLogTest(temp13, "size_t");
00211     OneLogTest(temp14, "PhysReal");
00212     OneLogTest(temp15, "PhysWhole");
00213     OneLogTest(temp16, "PhysString");
00214     OneLogTest(temp17, "PhysVector3");
00215     OneLogTest(temp18, "RawEvent"); /// @todo TODO Figure out How does this called the same streaming function as MetaCode ?!?!?
00216     OneLogTest(temp19, "MetaCode");
00217     OneLogTest(temp20, "btVector3");
00218     OneLogTest(temp21, "Ogre::Vector3");
00219 }
00220 
00221 template <class T> void PhysWorld::OneLogTest(T Data, string DataType, string Message1, string Message2)
00222 {
00223     try
00224     {
00225         Log(Message1+DataType);
00226         LogAndThrow(Data);
00227     } catch (T excepted) {
00228         Log(Message2+DataType);
00229         Log(excepted);
00230     }
00231 }
00232 
00233 ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00234 //tears the world down
00235 PhysWorld::~PhysWorld()
00236 {
00237         //Destroy the physical world that we loved and cherished
00238     delete BulletDynamicsWorld;
00239         delete BulletDispatcher;
00240         delete BulletCollisionConfiguration;
00241     delete BulletSolver;
00242         delete BulletBroadphase;
00243 
00244         //All the pointers Ogre made should get taken care of by OGRE
00245         delete OgreRoot;
00246 
00247         //clear up our objects
00248         delete CallBacks;
00249         delete Events;
00250 
00251         delete PlayerSettings;
00252 
00253         //remove sdl stuff
00254         SDL_FreeSurface(SDLscreen);
00255         SDL_Quit();
00256 }
00257 
00258 ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00259 //appends to the gamelog which is managed by Ogre
00260 template <class T> void PhysWorld::Log(T Message)
00261 {
00262         stringstream temp;
00263         temp << Message;
00264         Ogre::LogManager::getSingleton().logMessage(temp.str());
00265 }
00266 
00267 template <class T> void PhysWorld::LogAndThrow(T Message)
00268 {
00269         this->Log(Message);
00270         throw(Message);
00271 }

00273 ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00274 //Shows the ogre settings Dialog, and allows it to save settings to ogres
00275 //preset save location
00276 bool PhysWorld::ShowSystemSettingDialog()
00277 {
00278         try
00279         {
00280                 return this->OgreRoot->showConfigDialog();
00281         } catch (exception& e) {
00282                 this->Log("Ogre settings windows from main UI or mandatory setting failure");
00283                 this->Log(e.what());
00284                 return false;
00285         }
00286 }

00288 ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00289 // Start the Game already
00290 void PhysWorld::GameInit(const bool &CallMainLoop )
00291 {
00292         //try to load the ogre config
00293         this->LoadOgreSettings();
00294         this->CreateRenderWindow();
00295 
00296     if(CallMainLoop)
00297     {
00298         MainLoop();
00299     }
00300 }
00301 
00302 void PhysWorld::MainLoop()
00303 {
00304     //Create a the RenderTimer, which will be used to measure the time
00305     Ogre::Timer RenderTimer;
00306 
00307         bool Callbackbools[] = {true, true, true, true, true, true};
00308 
00309         //Used for tracking times to prevent Infinite render loops in graphically simple games
00310         //PhysWhole Times[] = {0,0,0,0};
00311 
00312         this->OgreSceneManager->setAmbientLight( Ogre::ColourValue( 1, 1, 1 ) );
00313 
00314     PhysWhole FrameDelay = 0;
00315     PhysWhole FrameTime = 0;
00316 
00317     /*! @page mainloop1 Main Loop Structure and Flow
00318      The MainLoop is heart of most vidoe games and simulations.
00319 
00320      @section overview1 Main loop Overview
00321          The Main loop runs in PhysWorld.MainLoop() which is called by default from @ref PhysWorld.GameInit(). By default this Method also starts the render, the physics andthe input systems. It does very little
00322          on it's own. It uses the default callback manager (which you can swap out if you want), which is the callback manager point to by PhysWorld::CallBacks . Once started it runs the
00323          callbacks present in the callback manager until one of them returns false. It has a pretty specific work flow. Starting with input, then physics, then rendering. There is a callback
00324          before and after each of these tasks.
00325      \n \n The user input task is never started if there is no Pre or Post callback set. It won't crash or throw any weird error condtions, it was specifically designed this way. This
00326      allows the input buffering to be turned off by simply removing the callbacks. This might not sound like much, but if you simply don't need input this can be a little performance bump.
00327      It sounds even better when we say it works the same way for physics. If you do not have a pre or post physic callback set physics simply is not run. This allows for easy control over
00328      the state of motion  in a world. Currently Rendering is performed each iteration of the main loop, regardless of what Callbacks are set. This may be changed at some point in the future,
00329      but no immediate plans to change it are in the works.
00330      \n \n One iteration of the main loops is about 1/60 of a second (by default) and will render 1 frame and step physics about 1/60 (1/62.5 usually) of a second. Currently there is no way to uncap
00331      the framerate, we did not see a need for more (but the cap can be adjusted using PhysWorld::SetTargetFrameTime or PhysWorld::SetTargetFrameRate ). Situations with low performance should
00332      automatically be handled but increasing the size of physics
00333      steps and automatically not rendering frames when not appropriate. There will be fewer calls on callbacks, but the engine will not inhibit gameplay below the the target framerate.
00334     \n
00335      @section callbacks1 1) Input Callbacks and Buffering
00336      User input is the first task performed each main loop. This was done because in most games and simulations everything depends on the user input.
00337      @subsection input1 1.A) PreInputCallback
00338      This can be set using the function in PhysWorldCallBackManager that have "PreInput" in their names. This is a great place to to do begining of loop items, like gathering data for
00339      computer controlled characters, checking if game goals are met, and other items that needs to be done it iteration of the game loop and don't directly relate to physics or Rendering.
00340      @subsection input2 1.B) Input Buffering
00341      During this step Input events are gathered fromt the input Subsystem (which could be any of a number of user input libraries), which are ultimately made by the Operating System and
00342      processed into PhysEventUserInput objects, and placed in the Default event manager ( check the pointer PhysWorld::Events ).
00343      @subsection input3 1.C) PostInputCallback
00344      This callback is your first chance to access the userinput Events and try to use them. This callback can be managed by using methods in PhysWorldCallBackManager that have "PostInput"
00345      in their names. The functionality of this Callback slightly overlaps with the Prephysics Callbacks due to the timing of using them both. If both are used, one will be called
00346      immediately after the other.
00347     \n
00348      @section callbacks2 2) Physics callbacks and Event Buffering
00349      This step runs between user input and rendering to allow for changes caused by user input to be immediately visible to the user.
00350      @subsection physics1 2.A) PrePhysicsCallback
00351      The funtionality of this callback overlaps a great deal with the PostInputCallBack, but they both still exist to make organization easier when needed. You probably should have figured
00352      out by now how the Callbackmanager functions are named, the ones for this are ituitively named with "PrePhysics" in their name.
00353      @subsection physics2 2.B) Physics calculations and Event Buffering
00354      Physics will be run here, but currently is not fully implemented. But eventually physics event will be generated here. Including a system for checking for certain types of collisions.
00355      @subsection physics3 2.C) PostPhysicsCallback
00356      This Callback is you first chance to work with the physics events just generated. This is a good place to check if you want items to adjust hitpoints, explode, die or take some other
00357      action based on physics.
00358     \n
00359      @section callbacks3 3) Rendering
00360      Unlike Input and Physics this rendering will be performed each Frame regardless of what callbacks are set. Rendering is done
00361      last so that any changes to the game world physics makes are made visible in the same loop iteration.
00362      @subsection rendering1 3.A) PerRenderCallback
00363      Any tasks that could not be complete in the PostPhysics Callback can be performed here or you use this to make last minute
00364      preparations for rendering.
00365      @subsection rendering2 3.B) Rendering
00366      This is where the rendering actually occurs. The state of all the items in the world is grabbed from the physics subsystem
00367      and rendered. Additionally this is where the \ref FrameDelay is calculated and acted on, so the frame rate can stay consistent.
00368      @subsection rendering3 3.C) PostRenderCallback
00369      This is a great place to switch out the Callback Manager, for accomplishing tasks like switching between in game menus and
00370      actual gameplay. This is also a decent place to get a head start on anything that would be run in the PreInputCallback.
00371     \n
00372      @section endingmainloop1 Ending the Main Loop
00373      The main loop stores the return values of each of the 6 callbacks. If they are all true the mainloop continues to it's
00374      next iteration. If one or more of any of the callbacks returns false then the main loop ends, and the game engine exits
00375      gracefully, cleanly up the physics, graphics and any others subsystems it opened.
00376      No attempt will be made by the engine to clean up data in the callback manager. If the game code does not free these items
00377      the operating system had better do it automatically. On most PC platform this is not an issue, but it could be disastrous
00378      on a mobile, or underperforming gaming platform.
00379         */
00380         //As long as all the CallBacks return true the game continues
00381         while (Callbackbools[0] && Callbackbools[1] && Callbackbools[2] && Callbackbools[3] && Callbackbools[4] && Callbackbools[5])
00382         {
00383         //Input buffering Callbacks
00384         if( this->CallBacks->IsPreInputCallbackSet() || this->CallBacks->IsPostInputCallbackSet() )
00385         {
00386                 if( this->CallBacks->IsPreInputCallbackSet() )
00387                 { Callbackbools[0] = this->CallBacks->PreInput(); }
00388                         this->DoMainLoopInputBuffering();
00389                         if( this->CallBacks->IsPostInputCallbackSet() )
00390                 { Callbackbools[1] = this->CallBacks->PostInput(); }
00391         }
00392 
00393         //Physics & Physics Callbacks
00394                 if( this->CallBacks->IsPrePhysicsCallbackSet() || this->CallBacks->IsPostPhysicsCallbackSet() )
00395         {
00396             if( this->CallBacks->IsPrePhysicsCallbackSet() )
00397                 { Callbackbools[2] = this->CallBacks->PrePhysics(); }
00398                         this->DoMainLoopPhysics(FrameTime);
00399             if( this->CallBacks->IsPostPhysicsCallbackSet() )
00400                 { Callbackbools[3] = this->CallBacks->PostPhysics(); }
00401         }
00402 
00403         //PreRender callback
00404                 if(this->CallBacks->IsPreRenderCallbackSet())
00405         {
00406             Callbackbools[4] = this->CallBacks->PreRender();
00407                         this->DoMainLoopWindowManagerBuffering();
00408         }
00409 
00410                 //Render the frame and figure the amount of time it took //By default Limit frame rate to 62.5
00411                 this->DoMainLoopRender();
00412                 FrameTime = RenderTimer.getMilliseconds();
00413                 RenderTimer.reset();
00414                 if(this->TargetFrameLength>FrameTime){
00415                     FrameDelay++;
00416                 }else if(this->TargetFrameLength==FrameTime){
00417         }else{
00418             if (0<FrameDelay){
00419                 FrameDelay--;
00420             }else{
00421                 FrameDelay=0;
00422             }
00423         }
00424         crossplatform::WaitMilliseconds( FrameDelay );
00425 
00426         //PostRender Callback
00427                 if(this->CallBacks->IsPostRenderCallbackSet())
00428         {
00429                         this->Events->AddEvent(new EventRenderTime(FrameTime));
00430                         Callbackbools[5] = this->CallBacks->PostRender();
00431         }
00432 
00433         }//End of main loop
00434 
00435         //Some after loop cleanup
00436         this->DestroyRenderWindow();
00437 }
00438 
00439 void PhysWorld::MoveCamera(const PhysVector3 &Position, const PhysVector3 &LookAt)
00440 {
00441         this->OgreCamera->setPosition(Ogre::Vector3(Position.X,Position.Y,Position.Z));
00442     this->OgreCamera->lookAt(Ogre::Vector3(LookAt.X,LookAt.Y,LookAt.Z));
00443 }
00444 
00445 void PhysWorld::DoMainLoopAllItems(const PhysReal &PreviousFrameTime)
00446 {
00447         this->DoMainLoopPhysics(PreviousFrameTime);
00448         this->DoMainLoopWindowManagerBuffering();
00449         this->DoMainLoopInputBuffering();
00450         this->DoMainLoopRender();
00451 }
00452 
00453 void PhysWorld::DoMainLoopPhysics(const PhysReal &TimeElapsed)
00454 {
00455     PhysReal FloatTime = TimeElapsed;
00456     FloatTime *= 0.0001;    //Convert from MilliSeconds to Seconds
00457 
00458     PhysReal IdealStep = this->TargetFrameLength;
00459     IdealStep *= 0.0001;
00460 
00461     //int MaxSteps = (FloatTime<IdealStep) ? 1 : int(FloatTime/IdealStep+1);
00462     int MaxSteps = (FloatTime<IdealStep) ? 1 : int(FloatTime/IdealStep+2);  //used 2 simply to be extra safe
00463     this->BulletDynamicsWorld->stepSimulation( FloatTime, MaxSteps, IdealStep);
00464     Log("Updated Physics");
00465 }
00466 
00467 void PhysWorld::DoMainLoopWindowManagerBuffering()
00468 {
00469     this->Events->UpdateSystemEvents();
00470 }
00471 
00472 void PhysWorld::DoMainLoopInputBuffering()
00473 {
00474     this->Events->UpdateUserInputEvents();
00475 }
00476 
00477 void PhysWorld::DoMainLoopRender()
00478 {
00479         crossplatform::RenderPhysWorld(this);
00480 }

00485 ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00486 //Loads the Ogre Configuration
00487 void PhysWorld::LoadOgreSettings()
00488 {
00489         //Try loading from the default location
00490         if (!this->OgreRoot->restoreConfig())
00491     {
00492         //if we can't do that then lets make new settings
00493         if (!this->ShowSystemSettingDialog())
00494         {
00495                 this->LogAndThrow("Error 1: Could not setup Ogre.");
00496                 }
00497     }
00498 }
00499 
00500 //Seriously read the Function Name
00501 void PhysWorld::CreateRenderWindow()
00502 {
00503     /// @todo TODO set multithreaded SDL so it will the run event manager in another thread
00504         //Get what is needed for SDL started
00505         if (SDL_Init(SDL_INIT_VIDEO) < 0) {
00506                 this->Log("Error 2: Unable to init SDL, SDL Error Follows:");
00507                 this->LogAndThrow(SDL_GetError());
00508         }
00509     this->HasSDLBeenInitialized=true;
00510 
00511         //Setup the SDL render window
00512         this->SDLscreen = SDL_SetVideoMode( PlayerSettings->getRenderWidth(), PlayerSettings->getRenderHeight(),0, SDL_OPENGL);
00513     SDL_WM_SetCaption(this->WindowName.c_str(), NULL);
00514 
00515         //Start Ogre Without a native render window
00516         this->OgreGameWindow = this->OgreRoot->initialise(false, this->WindowName);
00517 
00518         //Configure Ogre to render to the SDL window
00519         Ogre::NameValuePairList *misc;
00520         misc=(Ogre::NameValuePairList*) crossplatform::GetSDLOgreBinder();
00521         (*misc)["title"] = Ogre::String(this->WindowName);
00522         this->OgreGameWindow = this->OgreRoot->createRenderWindow(WindowName, PlayerSettings->getRenderHeight(), PlayerSettings->getRenderWidth(), PlayerSettings->getFullscreen(), misc);
00523 
00524         //prepare a scenemanager
00525         this->OgreSceneManager = this->OgreRoot->createSceneManager(Ogre::ST_GENERIC,"SceneManager");
00526 
00527         //setup a default camera
00528         this->OgreCamera = this->OgreSceneManager->createCamera("Camera");
00529         this->OgreCamera->setNearClipDistance(5.0f);
00530     this->OgreCamera->setFarClipDistance(5000.0f);
00531 
00532         this->MoveCamera(PhysVector3(0.0f,0.0f,500.0f), PhysVector3(0.0f,0.0f,0.0f));
00533 
00534         //viewport connects camera and render window
00535         this->OgreViewport = this->OgreGameWindow->addViewport(OgreCamera);
00536 
00537         //setting the aspect ratio must be done after we setup the viewport
00538         this->OgreCamera->setAspectRatio( Ogre::Real(OgreViewport->getActualWidth()) / Ogre::Real(OgreViewport->getActualHeight()) );
00539 }
00540 
00541 void PhysWorld::DestroyRenderWindow()
00542 {
00543     this->OgreGameWindow->destroy();
00544 }

00549 
00550 void PhysWorld::AddActor(ActorBase* ActorToAdd)
00551 {
00552     ActorToAdd->AddObjectToWorld(this, this->BulletDynamicsWorld);
00553 }

00555 ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00556 // Simple get and Set functions
00557 ///////////////////////////////////////
00558 std::string PhysWorld::GetWindowName()
00559 {
00560     return this->WindowName;
00561 }
00562 
00563 void PhysWorld::SetWindowName(const PhysString &NewName)
00564 {
00565     /// @todo TODO Change the name of an application once it is running
00566     WindowName = NewName;
00567     if(this->HasSDLBeenInitialized)
00568     {
00569         SDL_WM_SetCaption(WindowName.c_str(),WindowName.c_str());
00570     }
00571 }
